abstract.p: Dan Bruce letter, commenting on August 17 article on access to national parks and other wilderness by new wheelchair users, says wheelchairs do incredible damage to trails in such fragile areas

block.p: There is an important point to add to your Aug. 17 front-page article about three wheelchair users who made it to the new wheelchair-accessible hut in the White Mountains National Forest.

Wheelchairs do incredible damage to the trails in these fragile areas. Did anyone in the group do an environmental assessment before attempting the exploit or consider that the damage done to trail borders by their wheeled equipment may take years for nature to repair?
There is an important point to add to your Aug. 17 front-page article about three wheelchair users who made it to the new wheelchair-accessible hut in the White Mountains National Forest.

Wheelchairs do incredible damage to the trails in these fragile areas. Did anyone in the group do an environmental assessment before attempting the exploit or consider that the damage done to trail borders by their wheeled equipment may take years for nature to repair?

It might seem that anyone who opposes wheeled use of backcountry trails in mountain terrain is unfeeling. But it is selfish to insist that every place be wheelchair-accessible, even if it destroys the natural features of the trail for everyone else.
DAN BRUCE Hot Springs, N.C., Aug. 17, 2000
The writer founded the Center for Appalachian Trail Studies.
